Dear Ms. Gordy:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
7/27/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include
the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at (616) 204-6992 .
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel Records
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or her
current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation shall be conducted each year.
One of sixteen employee files did not have a performance evaluation completed as
required.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Six of eight foster care files did not have medical passports completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 8/2/22
2

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Four of six foster care and files held FTMs as required but did not have an 1105
report completed.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of eight foster care files did not have a dental completed within the timeframe
required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at
least every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
One of eight foster care files did not have a dental completed during an 18-month
period. Effective 7/3/23 new licensing rules require a dental exam every 9 months.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the
medical or dental provider of all medical and dental care
received by a foster child.
Three of eight foster care files indicated a medical or dental exam was completed.
However, the required documentation was not in the file.

Once completed and approved, the caseworker must

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Orientation: ILP staff orientation checklist should document a total number
of training hours completed.
• Dental exams: The agency was advised to review medical/dental exam
due dates as new licensing rules became effective 7/3/2023.
• Education record: The MiSACWIS education performance tab must be
updated for each child, every school year.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
6

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency had one CAP, approved 8/2/22. The CAP was a result of the 7/6/22
renewal evaluation. Twenty-eight violations were found during the 2022 review.
During the current review fourteen violations were identified. Six were repeat
violations from 2022. Overall, the agency has improved in several areas. The
agency reported successful implementation of their CAP in many areas. However,
staff turnover has hindered their ability to fully implement the CAP. The agency is
aware of the areas of needed improvement and will address them in the 2023
CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed on-site. The
Chief Administrator (CA) reported improvement in many areas as shown in their
increased Key Performance Indicators. However, there continues to be some
difficulty with timeliness of documents. Specifically, medicals and dentals, due to a
provider shortage in the area. The agency continues to troubleshoot this issue and
try new strategies. The CA reported significant improvement in their Independent
Living Plus program (ILP), as they have completed their first year of ILP. The CA
acknowledged some struggles at the beginning of the year, but report there has
been significant improvement in many areas, which has helped make the program
run more smoothly. The CA reported there is a lot of focus on updating
policy/procedures to comply with the licensing rules that became effective 7/3/23.
The agency is also focusing on staff hiring and retention, as there was significant
staff turnover this past year. Staff turnover has affected the agency’s ability to
maintain compliance in some areas. However, the CA and supervisory staff
continue to review the CAP often and work on it with all staff.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. One staff was new to the agency, the other
had been there for two years. Both staff report feeling supported by their
supervisors. The new staff indicated it was challenging to balance training and
learning their caseload. However, their supervisor was helpful in managing things.
Neither staff identified any areas the agency could improve in.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in an office building in Lansing. The agency has been in this
building for several years. There is adequate space for staff to work and hold
family visitation. Locking file storage was viewed and found to be sufficient.
7

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
